text: Hi, I developed custom modules for each row of a website, each with its own CSS. In GTMetrix I’m getting a lot of server requests for those CSS files. Would it be better to create separate CSS files and call for those in the main CSS file? Would that reduce requests, or would be the same thing? Thanks in advance!

Hi Antonio what do you mean by a lot of requests? I'm currently building themes and  using custom modules then I inject CSS and JS in each module. This has greatly reduced the weight of the pages and JS blocking issues. I can't be for certain but I would think one of the reason HubSpot is moving to this model is it reduces the overhead of irrelevant CSS and JS that effects page loading. I don't work for HubSpot so I'm just making some big assumptions.

Hi <@UTQQ4TXCH> Each row on the homepage is a customized module. Those modules are creating a CSS request seen in the waterfall. In just one page I have 18 CSS requests. I think that’s a lot.  <https://gtmetrix.com/reports/www.koncert.com/MuzHU0lH/>
Thanks for the response Antonio that is very little requests for CSS in my opinion. What I see as an issue is you have 185 that is a lot where are they coming from?
Thank you Thomas! So, the client is using a lot of marketing tools they use are creating many scripts. I’m working on reducing that. Images are being combined now, if possible.

Sorry I missed that you actually shared the URL sorry about that and thanks for sharing. 74 requests are images lazy loading those will be a game changer. What that means is only images in the window will load all others will only load after scrolling.
You can also use sprites when approptiate.

No worries. So, even the default theme image fields are set to load image = browser default. But, it’s not lazy loading. I hard-coded some HTML with the loading=“lazy” attribute, but it’s not working. Have you ever experienced that?
